title: 114_s2278
content: The Act may be cited as the "Promoting Unlicensed Spectrum Act of 2015" and includes definitions for key terms. The "Promoting Unlicensed Spectrum Act of 2015" defines key terms including "appropriate committees of Congress," "Assistant Secretary," "Commission," "Federal entity," "Spectrum Relocation Fund," and "unlicensed operations." The text chunk refers to regulations for licensing under parts 15 and 96 of title 47, Code of Federal Regulations. The text chunk discusses the allocation and allotment of spectrum by the Federal Communications Commission. The Commission must ensure a balance between exclusive licensing and unlicensed operations in spectrum allocation. Within 18 months of the Act, rules must be established for future allocation, including potential unlicensed operations in auctioned spectrum. These rules must be included in auction service rules and reflected in reports to Congress. The National Strategy for Unlicensed Spectrum is outlined in Section 4 of the Act, which aims to establish rules for future allocation of spectrum, including potential unlicensed operations in auctioned spectrum. The National Strategy for Unlicensed Spectrum aims to maximize spectrum utility, promote innovation in wireless broadband, and ensure a balanced spectrum policy. It includes developing a strategy for making additional radio frequency bands available for unlicensed operations, clearing bands for unlicensed devices, and considering spectrum sharing rules. The National Strategy for Unlicensed Spectrum aims to maximize spectrum utility and promote innovation in wireless broadband. It includes considering rules for spectrum sharing to expand opportunities for unlicensed operations, improving databases for spectrum access, and exploring additional bands for unlicensed use. The Commission will submit a report to Congress within 1 year of the Act's enactment, detailing the strategy for unlicensed spectrum use and any legislative recommendations. The report will also be made publicly available on the Commission's website. SEC. 5. MAKING FEDERAL SPECTRUM AVAILABLE FOR UNLICENSED OPERATION. The Assistant Secretary, along with the Commission and the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, must submit a report to Congress within 270 days of this Act's enactment on designating additional radio frequency bands for unlicensed operations by Federal entities without causing interference. Recommendations on reforming the Spectrum Relocation Fund and ensuring its solvency, as well as exploring the possibility of permitting unlicensed operations in spectrum bands used by Federal entities, will be considered in the report. The report must assess the feasibility of allowing unlicensed operations in Federal spectrum bands without causing interference to government operations, including homeland security and national security communications. It should also explore alternative spectrum sharing techniques to enable access by radio technologies conducting unlicensed operations in Federal spectrum.
